SOHO/HARLEM Africa Photographed From the Inside

''Africa by Africans: A Photographic Essay'' presents a perspective of sub-Saharan Africa from the inside, in contrast to the widely exhibited images from of ethnologists, anthropologists and tourists. The exhibition, at the Museum for African Art, includes 70 photographs spanning 150 years.

In addition, a joint exhibition at the Museum for African Art and the Studio Museum in Harlem titled ''Beads, Body, and Soul: Art and Light in the Yoruba Universe'' presents 150 objects of beaded art from the Yoruba in Nigeria, the Republic of Benin and their descendants in Brazil, Cuba and the United States. The beaded throne shown below, made in Nigeria, is of beads, leather, cloth, wicker, thread and nails.

''Africa by Africans: A Photographic Essay'' and ''Beads, Body and Soul'' Museum for African Art, through Aug. 27, Tuesday through Friday, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m., Saturday and Sunday noon to 6 p.m, closed Mondays and July 4; 593 Broadway, near Houston Street; adults, $5; students, children 12 and under and people over 65, $2.50; free on Sundays; (212) 966-1313.

''Beads, Body, and Soul'' through Sept. 17, Studio Museum in Harlem; Wednesday and Thursday, noon to 6 p.m.; Friday noon to 8 p.m., weekends 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; closed Mondays, Tuesdays and major holidays; 144 West 125th Street (near Lenox Avenue); $5; $3, students and people over 65; $1, children under 12; (212) 864-4500.
FINANCIAL DISTRICT Manhattan Long Ago, Before Trump, Even

Brian McGrath, an architect, and Mark Watkins are developing a 3-D computer model that maps the formation and deformation of Manhattan's skyscraper districts through time. The project, ''Manhattan Timeformations,'' uses computer models and interactive animations to depict the relationship between Mahattan's skyscrapers and geologic formation, settlement patterns, transportation and communications infrastructure, and zoning laws.

The completed version will be on view at the Skyscraper Museum's permanent home in Battery Park City in 2001. In the meantime, the public is invited to view the model as a work in progress and meet the designers. Two sessions remain in June, and there will be more throughout the summer. For a complete listing of sessions, one may call or visit www.skyscraper.org.
''Manhattan Timeformations''; Wednesday 1 . to 3 p.m. and Thursday 6 to 8 p.m. ; Skyscraper Museum's temporary gallery, 110 Maiden Lane between Water and Pearl Streets; free; (212) 968-1961.
LOWER MANHATTAN Free Country, Free Concert

This is the land of the free; free concerts, that is. You can start celebrating Independence Day early with a concert on Saturday in Battery Park. It is sponsored by the Aliance for Downtown New York and Delta Airlines and is headlined by the pop singer Shawn Colvin and the folk-rocker Billy Bragg.

Ms. Colvin, pictured above, won a Grammy for Best Contemporary Folk Recording for her debut album, ''Steady On.'' In 1996 she won two more Grammys, Record of the Year and Song of the Year for ''Sunny Came Home.'' Ms. Colvin will perform without her band. Mr. Bragg will perform a collection from his more than 20 years in the music industry, including works from his recent collaboration on a tribute to Woody Guthrie.
Independence Weekend Concert; Saturday 3 p.m.; the Great Lawn of Battery Park; free; (212) 835-2789.
